note_text:
Met with Mr. Luca Bianchi on 12 February 2026 to review and document his source of wealth. Mr. Bianchi is an Italian national, resident in Milan, and has been a long-standing client of the bank. He has a background in property investment and has been building and managing a small residential property portfolio over several years.

Mr. Bianchi’s occupation is a self-employed property owner and landlord. He owns three residential apartments in Milan which are rented on long-term lease agreements to private tenants. He manages the properties directly and receives rental income on a monthly basis.

The source of wealth discussed relates to accumulated rental income in the total amount of EUR 21,639. Mr. Bianchi explained that this amount represents net rental income saved over the past 12 months after deduction of property-related expenses and local taxes. The income is generated solely from the rental of his owned properties and has been retained in his personal savings account.

Documentation provided includes copies of the property ownership deeds, current rental contracts for all three apartments, and bank statements showing regular rental income credits consistent with the stated amounts. An annual tax declaration reflecting declared rental income was also provided. All documents were clear, consistent, and aligned with the explanation given during the meeting.

My assessment is that the source of wealth is straightforward and well documented. The level of income is reasonable in relation to the size and location of the properties, and the accumulation of EUR 21,639 over the stated period is plausible. No unusual transactions or inconsistencies were identified.

No concerns or red flags noted. The customer demonstrated good understanding of his financial situation and was cooperative throughout the review. Source of wealth is considered satisfactorily verified.

note_text:
Met with customer Michael Turner on 14 Feb 2026 to discuss source of wealth in connection with recent funds credited to his account. Mr. Turner is a US citizen, age 46, with a professional background as a small business owner in the technology services sector. He has banked with us for several years and maintains a straightforward personal banking relationship.

Mr. Turner was the sole owner and managing director of Turner IT Solutions LLC, a locally registered IT support and consulting company established in 2014. He advised that he sold the business in December 2025 as part of a planned exit to focus on personal investments and consulting on a part-time basis.

The source of wealth discussed relates to proceeds from the sale of his company. Mr. Turner received USD 152,953 as net proceeds from the transaction, which were transferred directly from the buyer’s escrow account to his personal account with us. He confirmed this represents the final settlement amount after taxes and transaction costs.

Documentation provided includes a signed business sale agreement, closing statement from the escrow agent detailing the net proceeds of USD 152,953, and a copy of the wire transfer confirmation showing receipt of funds. Documents were reviewed and appear complete, consistent, and credible.

My overall assessment is that the customer provided a clear and straightforward explanation of his source of wealth, fully supported by documentation. The transaction size is reasonable given the nature and scale of the business described, and the flow of funds is transparent.

No concerns or red flags identified at this time. Source of wealth is assessed as acceptable and satisfactorily evidenced.

note_text:
Met with customer Daniel Whitmore on 12 Feb 2026 to discuss source of wealth relating to recent and expected inflows totalling approx. GBP 1,291,735. Customer is a UK national, resident in London, mid-40s. He describes himself as a “property investor and consultant” and previously worked in construction project management. Currently self-employed via a personal services company, Whitmore Advisory Ltd, incorporated in the UK.

Daniel advised that the majority of his wealth has been generated through property transactions over the last 8–10 years, combined with retained consulting income and an overseas investment. He presented the following breakdown, though figures changed slightly during the discussion:

1) Sale of UK residential property in Manchester – approx. GBP 865,000 net. Customer stated the property was purchased in 2016 for “around GBP 420k” and sold in October 2025 for GBP 1.02m. He initially stated net proceeds of GBP 890k, later revised this to GBP 865k after “fees and tax”. He has not yet provided a full completion statement. He shared a copy of the Land Registry title and a draft sale memorandum from the estate agent but did not have the solicitor’s completion statement or CGT calculation available. He stated the sale proceeds were first credited to his solicitor’s client account, then partially transferred to an account in his name at a different UK bank before being consolidated.

2) Consulting income retained over time – approx. GBP 210,000. Daniel stated this represents accumulated dividends and director’s loans drawn from Whitmore Advisory Ltd between 2019–2024. He was vague on exact dates and initially said “around GBP 250k”, then said some of that amount was “reinvested and spent”. He provided limited company accounts for FY2022 and FY2023 only, showing net profits broadly consistent with dividend payments, but no personal tax returns or dividend vouchers. He said his accountant holds those and can provide them if needed.

3) Overseas property investment in Spain – approx. GBP 145,000. Customer advised he co-invested in a small residential development in Valencia via a Spanish SL structure in 2018. He claims to have exited in mid-2024 and received EUR 170,000, which he converted to GBP “when rates were good”, estimating GBP 145k. He did not have supporting sale contracts or bank statements to evidence receipt. He mentioned the funds were initially paid to a Spanish bank account, which is now closed. He provided a copy of an old share certificate in the SL and a Spanish notary document, but these do not clearly show exit value. When asked why the account was closed, he said it was “no longer needed” and changed the subject.

Total wealth cited during the meeting ranged between GBP 1.27m and GBP 1.32m; after discussion we agreed the working figure is approx. GBP 1,291,735, though this remains approximate pending documentation.

Jurisdictions involved include the UK and Spain. Customer also briefly mentioned having “looked at opportunities” in Dubai but said no funds were ultimately invested there; this was not elaborated on.

Observations: Daniel was generally cooperative but imprecise with figures and timelines. He appeared confident discussing property but evasive when asked for exact dates, tax treatment, and bank flows, particularly regarding the Spanish investment and CGT on the UK sale. Some inconsistencies noted between verbal figures and documents shown on his phone. He often referred to his accountant or solicitor rather than providing direct answers.

Documents provided to date: UK passport copy, proof of UK address, Land Registry title for Manchester property, estate agent sale memorandum, limited company accounts (FY2022–2023), Spanish SL share certificate. Documents requested: solicitor’s completion statement for UK property sale, CGT computation, personal tax returns (last 3 years), dividend vouchers or director’s loan statements, bank statements showing receipt of sale proceeds, and evidence of exit and fund flow from Spanish investment.

Concerns/red flags: incomplete documentation for primary source of funds, inconsistent amounts stated for property sale proceeds, lack of clear audit trail for overseas investment and use of a now-closed foreign bank account, and vague explanations around tax. No immediate adverse information identified, but enhanced due diligence recommended before accepting full inflow.

figures approximate and partially undocumented"}, {"source_type": "investment", "amount": 145000, "currency": "GBP", "description": "Proceeds from overseas property development investment in Valencia, Spain via Spanish SL structure; note_text:
Met with Mr James Whitaker today to discuss the source of wealth relating to recent funds credited to his account. Mr Whitaker is a UK national, aged 42, and has been a personal banking customer with us since 2016. He is currently employed as a senior IT project manager at a multinational technology firm, where he has been working for over ten years. His employment income is stable and consistent with his overall financial profile.

The source of wealth discussed relates to investment returns totalling GBP 49,256. Mr Whitaker explained that these funds represent gains realised from a long-term investment portfolio held in his own name. The portfolio consists of listed equities, bond funds, and a global index tracker fund, all held through a well-known UK investment platform. Mr Whitaker provided recent investment account statements showing the sale of holdings and the resulting proceeds of GBP 49,256, as well as historical statements demonstrating the accumulation of the investments over time. He also provided a copy of his most recent P60 to support his ongoing employment and income position. All documents were clear, complete, and consistent with the explanation provided during the meeting.

My overall assessment is that the source of wealth is straightforward and credible. The investment activity is in line with the customer’s professional background and earning capacity, and the amounts involved are reasonable. There are no concerns or red flags identified at this time, and no further information is required.

note_text:
Met with customer Mr. Daniel Wong on 15 Feb 2026 to discuss the source of funds for an incoming cross-border transfer totaling USD 197,127.

Mr. Wong is a 38-year-old Singaporean national currently residing in London. He works as a Senior Software Engineering Manager with a multinational technology firm. He has been employed with the same employer for the past seven years, initially based in Singapore and relocated to the UK in 2022.

The source of wealth for the USD 197,127 is accumulated employment income and annual performance bonuses earned while working in Singapore and the UK. Mr. Wong explained that he maintained a savings account in Singapore where a portion of his salary and bonuses were deposited between 2018 and 2022. Following his relocation, he consolidated these savings and transferred the funds from his Singapore bank account to his UK account, from which the current transfer to our bank was initiated. The total amount represents long-term savings and does not include any business income, investments, or third-party funds.

Documents provided include:
- Employment contract and confirmation letter from current employer
- Payslips covering the last 12 months
- Singapore and UK personal bank statements showing salary credits and accumulation of savings
- Tax assessment notices from Singapore (IRAS) and the UK (HMRC)
- SWIFT transfer confirmation from the Singapore bank

All documents were reviewed and are consistent with the explanation provided. The flow of funds is clear and traceable across jurisdictions, with Mr. Wong named as the account holder at each stage. The amount is reasonable given his role, tenure, and compensation level.

Overall assessment is satisfactory. The source of wealth is transparent, well-documented, and aligns with the customer’s professional background. No concerns or red flags identified.

note_text:
Met with customer John Martinez today to discuss source of wealth in connection with the recent large credit. John is a 62-year-old US citizen, recently retired. He spent most of his career working as a project manager in the construction and engineering sector, last employed by a mid-sized infrastructure firm in Texas. He retired in late 2024.

Total funds under review are USD 466,526. Primary source is a pension lump sum payment of approximately USD 382,000 received in November 2025 from his former employer’s defined benefit pension plan. John explained this was paid out upon retirement as a one-time lump sum rather than monthly payments. He provided a copy of the pension payout statement and a partial benefits summary, though the full plan document and final tax statement were not available at the meeting.

Secondary source is a rollover from a 401(k) account held with Fidelity, amounting to around USD 58,500. This was transferred into his personal account earlier this year after he consolidated his retirement accounts. He showed screenshots from the Fidelity app confirming the rollover, but has not yet provided the official rollover confirmation letter.

The remaining USD 26,026 comes from accumulated personal savings over the years, mainly salary savings and annual bonuses. John stated these funds were held in a checking and savings account with Bank of America prior to transfer. No historical bank statements were provided yet, only the most recent statement showing the outgoing transfer.

Documents provided so far include: pension lump sum statement, recent bank statement showing receipt of funds, and a copy of his retirement letter from his employer. Documents still requested: full pension plan summary, 401(k) rollover confirmation, and last year’s tax return to confirm retirement income and tax treatment of the lump sum.

My overall assessment is that the source of wealth is generally consistent with John’s age, career history, and retirement status. Amounts are reasonable for his stated employment background. Minor concern around incomplete documentation, particularly the lack of formal confirmation for the 401(k) rollover and full pension details, but no immediate red flags. John was cooperative, understood the requests, and agreed to provide the remaining documents within the next two weeks.

note_text:
Met with customer James O’Connell today to discuss recent and anticipated inbound funds totaling GBP 233,326. James is a dual UK/Irish national, currently UK resident for the past 6 years. He works as a senior project manager for a multinational engineering firm and also has some legacy overseas assets.

James explained that the funds are coming from a combination of three sources across different jurisdictions:

1) Approx. GBP 148,000 from the sale of an apartment in Dublin, Ireland. Property was inherited from his aunt in 2018 and sold in November last year. He provided a copy of the Irish solicitor’s completion statement and the estate distribution letter, but the final bank-to-bank transfer confirmation from the Irish solicitor’s client account is still pending. He expects to receive this shortly.

2) Approx. GBP 55,000 from accumulated employment savings held in a Singaporean bank account. James worked in Singapore between 2014–2019 and retained a local account. He shared historical payslips from his employer at the time and a recent Singapore bank statement, though the statement only shows the closing balance and not the full transaction history. I have requested a longer statement covering at least the last 12 months.

3) Approx. GBP 30,326 from an investment portfolio liquidation in the UK (stocks and ETFs held with an online broker). He provided the broker’s transaction summary and a recent tax statement confirming capital gains declared in the UK.

Overall explanation was coherent and consistent with his background and career history. James was open in the discussion and understood the need for documentation. The cross-border element adds some complexity, and there are minor gaps around the full audit trail for the Irish property proceeds and the Singapore account history, but nothing appears inconsistent at this stage.

No immediate red flags identified. Main follow-up is to obtain the missing transfer confirmation from the Irish solicitor and extended bank statements from Singapore to complete the source of wealth file. Pending receipt of these, the source of funds explanation appears reasonable and proportionate to the amount involved.

note_text:
Met with customer John Ramirez today to discuss source of wealth for recent and anticipated account activity. John is a 42-year-old US citizen, currently residing locally, and has been a client of the bank since 2019. Background is fairly straightforward. He works as a senior product manager at a mid-sized technology company and has been in the tech sector for over 15 years. Annual salary approx. USD 145k plus variable bonus.

John explained that the primary source of wealth under review relates to investment returns totaling approximately USD 433,281 accumulated over the last 6–7 years. Breakdown as follows: approx. USD 245,000 from long-term equity investments (mainly US-listed stocks such as Apple, Microsoft, and several ETFs held via a brokerage account with Vanguard), approx. USD 128,000 from mutual funds and index funds (mix of S&P 500 and total market funds), and approx. USD 60,000 from bond funds and fixed income ETFs. He stated that most investments were funded through regular monthly contributions from salary and annual bonuses.

Documents provided during or after the meeting include recent brokerage statements covering the last 12 months and a summary portfolio report from Vanguard. These generally support the current balance and recent performance, but do not fully show the original cost basis or the full history of contributions. John indicated he may be able to request older statements if needed, though it may take some time as some investments date back to 2016–2017. We also requested last two years of tax returns to confirm declared investment income and capital gains; these have not yet been received.

My overall observation is that John was open, cooperative, and knowledgeable about his investments. The story is consistent with his professional profile and income level. Portfolio performance seems reasonable given market conditions, and there were no signs of unusual trading activity or third-party involvement. Minor concern is the lack of complete historical documentation showing how the full USD 433k accumulated over time, particularly earlier years. However, this appears to be a documentation gap rather than a substantive issue. No immediate red flags identified at this stage. Recommend follow-up once tax returns and, if possible, older brokerage statements are provided to complete the file.

note_text:
Met with Mr. Laurent Meyer today to discuss source of wealth in relation to recent funds credited to his account totaling EUR 665,255.

Customer background: Mr. Meyer is a French national, currently residing in Lyon. He is in his mid-40s and has been a long‑standing client of the bank since 2016. He has an entrepreneurial background and was the sole shareholder and managing director of a small logistics software company.

Occupation / business details: Mr. Meyer founded and operated LM Solutions SARL, a B2B software company providing route optimization tools for regional transport firms. The business was established in 2011 and employed approx. 12 staff at its peak. He confirmed that he sold 100% of his shares in the company in mid‑2025 to a larger German tech group.

Source(s) of wealth:
1) Sale of business – approx. EUR 620,000 net proceeds. Mr. Meyer explained that the gross sale price was around EUR 700,000, with deductions for taxes, legal fees, and advisory costs. The EUR 620,000 represents net proceeds received in two tranches, with the final payment credited last month.
2) Accumulated personal savings – approx. EUR 35,000. Savings built up over several years from salary and dividends paid by LM Solutions prior to the sale.
3) Minor investment income – approx. EUR 10,255 from a French investment fund portfolio held with another bank, recently transferred to consolidate funds.

Documents provided / requested: Mr. Meyer provided a signed share purchase agreement (SPA) summary and a bank statement showing receipt of the final sale proceeds. He also shared historic company financial statements for 2022–2024. Full SPA, proof of tax settlement on capital gains, and confirmation of the initial tranche payment are still outstanding and have been requested.

Observations and assessment: Customer was open and cooperative during the meeting and able to clearly explain the transaction and background of the business sale. His explanation aligns with the documents seen so far and with his profile as a long‑term business owner. The amounts involved are reasonable given the size and history of the company.

Concerns / red flags: No major red flags identified. Minor concern around incomplete documentation, specifically full tax confirmation and complete SPA, but customer acknowledged this and committed to providing the remaining documents within the next 2–3 weeks. Overall risk assessed as moderate and manageable pending receipt of outstanding documents.

note_text:
Met with customer Michael Thompson today to discuss source of wealth in relation to recent funds credited to his account.

Mr. Thompson is a 42-year-old U.S. citizen residing locally. He has been employed as a senior project manager with a multinational engineering firm for the past 12 years. He maintains stable employment income and has been a customer of the bank since 2018.

The source of wealth discussed relates to investment returns totaling USD 48,221. Mr. Thompson explained that these funds were generated from a long-term personal investment portfolio held with Vanguard. The amount consists of realized gains and dividends from a diversified portfolio of U.S. equities and bond index funds, accumulated over the past 18 months and liquidated in December. This is his sole source of wealth for the transaction under review.

Documentation provided includes the full Vanguard brokerage statements showing portfolio holdings, transaction history, realized capital gains, and dividend income, as well as the redemption confirmation and bank transfer advice. Documents were clear, consistent, and matched the amount received.

Mr. Thompson was knowledgeable about his investments and provided a straightforward explanation. His profile, employment history, and financial behavior are consistent with the level and nature of the investment returns.

No concerns or red flags identified. Source of wealth is reasonable, transparent, and fully supported by documentation. Account activity aligns with expected use and risk profile.

note_text:
Met with customer: Daniel Harper, age 41. Daniel is a US citizen currently residing locally for work. He comes across as open and cooperative, answered questions without hesitation. Background is fairly straightforward, no prior relationship with the bank.

Occupation: Daniel works as a senior project manager for a mid-sized construction consultancy (Harper & Cole Consulting LLC). Employed there since 2016. Annual salary approx. USD 115k–125k based on his explanation, plus occasional performance bonuses. He is not an owner in the business and does not receive dividends.

Source of wealth discussed in today’s meeting:

Primary source is inherited wealth from his late aunt, Margaret Lewis, who passed away in November 2024. Daniel explained he was one of two beneficiaries of her estate. His portion of the estate transfer totaled USD 572,528, which was distributed to him in two tranches from the estate’s attorney-managed escrow account. Funds were received in December 2024 and January 2025 and are now sitting in his personal checking account pending longer-term planning.

Secondary sources include accumulated employment savings of approximately USD 180,000 built up over the last 10+ years from salary, plus around USD 45,000 in a brokerage account invested in mutual funds and ETFs. These are not being transferred at this stage but were discussed to understand overall profile.

Documents provided: Daniel shared a copy of the estate distribution letter from the law firm handling the probate, showing his name and the total inheritance amount. He also provided recent bank statements reflecting the incoming transfers. Copy of death certificate was not available at the meeting; he said he can request one from the attorney if required. No full probate court documents provided yet.

Documents requested: Asked Daniel to provide a copy of the will or probate summary confirming beneficiary status, and either the death certificate or a formal confirmation letter from the estate attorney. Also requested last two years of tax returns to confirm reporting of inheritance and employment income.

Observations and assessment: Inheritance story is consistent and aligns with the transaction history shown. Amount and timing make sense given probate timelines. Daniel appears financially literate but not sophisticated; main goal is capital preservation with some moderate growth. He mentioned plans to use part of the funds for a home purchase in the next 12–18 months.

Concerns / red flags: Minor documentation gaps at this stage, mainly around probate confirmation, but nothing that raises significant concern. Estate was domestic (US-based), no offshore structures or complex vehicles involved. Will follow up once remaining documents are received, but overall source of wealth appears legitimate and manageable from a KYC perspective.
